Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: Reorganization of stresses beneath greater Tokyo after the 2011 Tohoku-Oki M9 earthquake
Award.AbstractNarration:
The March 11, 2011, Tohoku-Oki earthquake at magnitude 9 was the largest event in Japan's 1400+ years of recorded history. The impact of the earthquake and resulting tsunami on the people of Japan was severe, from the approximately 20,000 fatalities and unaccounted persons to the estimated Â¥10 trillion (US$ 120 billion) of economic loss. The Tohoku-Oki rupture was located north of Tokyo, leading to a strong societal interest within Japan as to what is in store for their capital city. Specifically, whether the Tohoku-Oki earthquake may have accelerated the next significant earthquake to more directly impact the Tokyo metropolitan region. Recent Japan government studies estimate that a shallow megathrust earthquake similar to the 1923 M7.9 "Great Kanto" earthquake would result in ~11,000 fatalities and up to US$ 3 trillion in economic damage. Concern for a worsening of seismic hazards in Tokyo region is warranted based on recent advances in earthquake science that indicate (a) that an earthquake that relieves stress in one area will build up stress in adjacent areas, and (b) while stress changes occur rapidly during the earthquake, postseismic processes will lead to the redistribution of crustal stresses for years to many decades after a large earthquake. Understanding the ongoing time-evolution of stress buildup in the Tokyo region adjacent to the 2011 Tohoku-Oki rupture, and its influence on active faults in that region is the primary objective of this NSF-supported project. This project is a collaboration with Japanese scientists who seek improved estimates of seismic hazards in the Tokyo region both currently and for decades to come. This project will provide research training to U.S. students, as well as international research experience, and also seeks to help our Japanese colleagues improve their ability to conduct this type of seismic hazard research.
This project seeks to understand the evolution of crustal stresses and associated seismic hazards in the Tokyo region in the years and decades to following the Tohoku-Oki earthquake. Stress changes will occur due to two primary postseismic processes, afterslip and viscoelastic relaxation. The former is associated with aseismic slip along the North America/Pacific plate interface within and below the region of coseismic slip, while the latter involves the relaxation of hot weak mantle beneath the converging plates. Both processes will cause a time-dependent transfer of stress to the seismogenic upper crust. It is our goal to understand this process of stress transfer and how it works to load active faults in the Tokyo region. This will be achieved by developing an observationally constrained finite element model that can accurately calculate stress changes due to afterslip and viscoelastic relaxation. Observational constraints will primarily consider seismological data that describes the tectonic geometry and elastic structure of the region, and geodetic constraints that will enable a determination of the rheology (viscous strength) of the region. Most importantly, the model should enable us to separate out the relative contributions of afterslip and viscous relaxation to postseismic geodetic data, which is not only required for an accurate calculation of stress changes, but will provide invaluable insights as to the nature of these two processes that will benefit our general understanding of subduction zone tectonics. It is the unprecedented postseismic GPS coverage within Japan that will enable these insights to be achieved.

ProgramReference.Text: STUDIES OF THE EARTH'S DEEP INTERIOR

POR.DRECONTENT:
Intellectual Merit.  Earthquakes not only release a great amount of energy, the reorganize the stress field, causing crustal stresses to increase in some regions. This reorganization can push nearby faults closer to failure, causing a sequence of earthquakes. In this light, the great 2011 M9 Tohoku, Japan earthquake may have pushed active faults in the densely populated Tohoku region closer to failure. To understand the change in seismic hazard in the Tokyo region, one must understand how stresses were changed by the earthquake, as well due to postseismic processes. One major postseismic process is afterslip, which happens when regions of the fault that did not slip during the earthquake slip afterwards aseismically. The other major postseismic process is viscoelastic relaxation, which occurs when coseismic stresses increase viscously weak (hot) regions of the crust or mantle. These stresses cannot be sustained and cause the rocks to flow. Both postseismic processes cause stresses to migrate to the upper crust, causing surface displacements that can be geodetically observed by GPS. Japan has the densest GPS array in the world that recorded surface displacements due to both coseismic slip (the earthquake) and postseismic processes (afterslip and viscoelastic relaxation). If we develop a numerical model that can simulate fault slip and viscoelastic relaxation, we can use these geodetic constraints to understand the distribution of slip during the earthquake, the distribution of afterslip, and the viscoelastic rheology associated with the subduction zone that Japan sits on top. This not only provides us insight into the nature of these important processes, but also then allows us to track stress changes due to these processes and evaluate how these stress changes have influenced seismic hazards in the Tokyo region.

      For this project, we developed a 3-D, viscoelastic finite element model of the M9 2011 Tohoku-oki, Japan earthquake, including the seismically inferred slab geometries associated with the subducting Pacific and Philippine Sea Plates. We used an inversion method constrained by GPS displacements to infer a coseismic slip distribution in which slip was greatest at the trench and decayed with depth – unusual for a large subduction zone earthquake which usually concentrate slip at 20 to 50 km depth where faults are generally stronger. Our maximum inferred slip of ~45 m is also much greater than previously observed for other large earthquakes. After inferring the coseismic slip distribution, we applied it to the model to calculate coseismic stress changes that will drive viscoelastic relaxation. Using a trial and error approach (because 3D relaxation is highly non-linear), we tested a large number of candidate viscoelastic rheologies to explain the 5-year cumulative observed postseismic surface displacements. For each candidate rheology, we calculated the predicted postseismic displacements and subtracted them from the observed postseismic displacements. We then used these residual displacements to invert for afterslip. In this fashion we studied a large number of combined viscoelastic relaxation and afterslip models to fully explain the observed postseismic displacements. We are able to find a rheological model that fully explains all observed geodetic on-land and seafloor horizontal and vertical postseismic displacements – this had never been accomplished before to this level of accuracy. We found that postseismic displacements are in about equal parts due to viscoelastic relaxation and afterslip, but their patterns are spatially distinct. The inferred rheology includes a mantle wedge viscosity structure that is depth dependent, reflecting the manner in which temperature, pressure, and water content influence viscosity. Observed westward-directed postseismic seafloor displacements may be due flow via low-temperature, plastic creep within the lower half of a Pacific lithosphere weakened by plate bending or due to a thin, weak oceanic asthenospheric layer. The distribution of afterslip appears to be controlled by the location of coseismic slip from the Tohoku-oki and previous regional historic tsunami-causing earthquakes, a result that appears to outline the manner in which the subducting Pacific plate gets stuck on its way down, eventually giving rise to large earthquakes.

Broader Impacts. Our calculations of stress changes due to coseismic and postseismic processes indicates that several active faults in the Tokyo region were pushed closer to failure by about 0.5 MPa, which may correspond to an advancement in the earthquake clock of about 30 years. Stress changes will continue to build in the decades to come due to continued viscoelastic relaxation. These results serve to help the Japanese seismic community assess the current state of seismic hazards in the Tokyo region. In addition, this project served as an opportunity to conduct a technology transfer to our colleague in Japan with respect to the techniques of finite element model development and postseismic analysis. Through the course of the project the PI worked with a Japanese postdoc and gave several seminars at the U. of Tokyo.
